message: In many cases I find it more ready for daily use than 3.x.
Chrome still packs in the speed.  I have FF 4 Beta in permanent private mode + no tracking as a "Guest" browser
i have the latest beta but I still prefer Chrome
Anybody using it? Is it ready for daily use?
Is FF private mode any better than Chrome's?
I guess most of us are Chrome fans first
btw, how do you like Convore?  Do you think it will catch on or go the way of Pownce?
@GordMcLeod That is great to hear. Other guys: I use Chrome for work, and I know I want FF as my fun browser. Given that I'm used to v3.6, I expect the speed bump in 4b will be a pleasant surprise.
I use it as a secondary browser after Chrome.
I've been Fx4 nightlies for months and love it. But then, I work at Mozilla.

Using FF4 with Prospector - Home Dash https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/prospector-home-dash/ is kinda awesome. It removes all the chrome and leaves just a very browsing-focused experience. It can be a bit discombobulating at first, without navigation bar or awesome bar, but used together with Pentadactyl http://dactyl.sourceforge.net/pentadactyl/ for keyboard navigation, it makes for a fresh new experience.
FF4, for background loading of tabs behaviour, mozilla sync working much better than chrome builtin + plugins, general feeling.

I've been using it for the past couple of days and I really do like it. :) I'm playing Browser Disco lately, swapping between Chrome, Firefox, and Opera. Personally, my favorite was Opera 11, but there are some rendering issues that I just couldn't live with. Firefox's Tab-Candy is a beautiful feature; I just can't get into the habit of using it though. Opera has Tab-Stacking where you can drag tabs on top of each other and form groups, it works much better because I don't have to go to a new page to organize everything.

FF4 for about a month now.  Some things were hard to get used to, like the moving status bar and the switched locations for new tab/window in context menu.  It's great though.  Once they fix the vimeo bug I won't need to keep a 2nd browser around.
Does it still have the bad memory leak problems that the previous versions did?
@jarod73 I hope not... I sincerely hope not. That's what got me to switch to Chrome. I'll probably be back as soon as that's fixed.

I was initially turned off from Firefox 4 because back in October I ran into an issue where it would periodically crash my video driver. I gave it another shot in February, though, and I've been loving it so far now that the issue has been resolved. I've been using it much more than Chrome.
Firefox is one of the few cases in which I unabashedly indulge in fanboism. :P Chewing through 60-70% of my RAM while I wasn't doing anything was just a bit too much. :(

@micrypt That's one of the initial reasons that I switched away from Firefox, too. So far 4 hasn't been as bad, though I still feel the need to keep an eye on memory usage, which is something that doesn't happen when I'm using other browsers. It's going to be a tough stigma for Firefox to shake.

at this point i like chrome so much im not sure if i would switch back to firefox... the irony is that i liked firefox for the speed and the google toolbar... chrome has the speed just not the toolbar, but with the add ons it doesnt matter anymore :)
